review.title: Causal inference for cloud computing
review.abstract: Two challenges in the theory and practice of cloud computing are: (1) smart control (allocation) of resources under exploration constraints, on time-varying systems, and (2) understanding and debugging of the performance of complex systems that involve e.g. virtualization. In this paper, we examine how these challenges can be approached using causal models. For challenge (1) we investigate how to infer and use causal models and selection diagrams to design and integrate experiments in a principled way, as well as to cope with partially varying systems. For challenge (2) we examine how to formalize performance attribution and debugging questions by counterfactual probabilities, and how to approximately answer them based on inferred (non-deterministic) graphical causal models.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 160 3.01 581v 1 [cs.A I] 4 Mar 2Two challenges in the theory and practice of cloud computing are: (1) intelligent resource allocation under exploration constraints, on time-varying systems, and (2) understanding and debugging the performance of complex systems, such as virtualization. In this paper, we examine how these challenges can be addressed with causal models; (1) how we can derive and use causal models and selection diagrams to design and integrate experiments in principle and deal with partially varying systems; (2) how to formalize performance attributions and debugging questions through counterfactual probabilities, and how to roughly answer them on the basis of inferred (non-deterministic) graphical causal models.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In recent years, the paradigm and business model of cloud computing [Crossbow et al., 2010] has become increasingly popular, allowing computing resources to be rented on-demand and used efficiently by intelligently sharing them. However, it also poses new challenges in terms of understanding, debugging and managing the complex systems involved. In this paper, we are investigating how causal models [Pearl, 2000, Spirtes et al., 2000] can help address two of these challenges. Note that we are not here aiming to present mature methodology; we are examining how causal models can be applied to different aspects of cloud computing, drawing inspiration from the kind of problems cloud computing generates. We find that a number of concepts commonly used in cloud computing explain concepts directly to concepts from theory of crucial models (in particular counterfactual models and selection diagrams) in our paper, and explain them as contexts.

sections.heading: 3.2 Problem 2: observation-level performance attribution and debugging
sections.text: Problem formulation. Performance mapping in computer systems means understanding which component of a system contributes to the measured performance, and to what extent. (Part of the problem is that there are currently no strict and general definitions of many concepts. We hope that with this paper we will also contribute a little to making the definitions stricter, as far as this is reasonable.) Such mapping is often an important step for debugging performance, i.e. for modifying certain system components to achieve the goal of performance improvement. In cloud computing, performance mapping and debugging is not trivial due to the complexity of the system, but crucial: for example, in the case of poor performance of an application running on a cloud server in a VM, you want to understand whether this problem needs to be attributed to the configuration of the VM (which you could change directly) or to the configuration of the server or other VMs on the server (in this case, you may have to purchase meaningful cloud products).

sections.heading: 7 Related work
sections.text: To our knowledge, this is the first paper to use causal models such as those introduced by Pearl [2000], Spirtes et al. [2000] to solve control and performance debugging problems in cloud computing or in complex computer systems in general. Ostrowski et al. [2011], Snee et al. [2015] investigate the problem of performance mapping and debugging of cloud systems, but without causal models that can lead to errors, as briefly discussed in Section 5.3. Baah et al. [2010] apply causal models to the debugging of programs, but not of entire computer systems. Bottou et al. [2013], Bareinboim et al. [2015] apply causal models to RL problems, as we do. However, their models are not applicable to the scenario considered in Section 4. For example, they do not address the problem of development and knowledge transfer from a separate experimental (computer system) to the design of controllers.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: This paper translates several important issues from cloud computing into causal consequence terminology, such as selection diagrams and counterfactors. Building on this, we propose methods to derive controllers from experimental and time-varying systems, as well as performance attributions and debugging at the observation level. Our work is only the beginning of what we consider to be a fruitful direction, and leaves several open problems and suggestions for future work. It would be highly desirable to develop tests based on causal and / or probable methods to verify how accurate a model is or whether and what additional measurements should be made. Furthermore, time models should have the potential to be more precise due to strong intertemporal influences in real systems. Annex
